title: Character Letter for Saleh in Beirut

messages.content:
i want to write a character witness sort of letter for a judge in beirut for my friend saleh Here's some background information on him and the house we started in beirut called beit al atlas: **History تاريخ**
The house started two years ago when Saleh and Bilal were cleaning up the aftermath of a flood in the house. Saleh was Bilal’s student at a UNICEF funded project run by Nawaya where Bilal was working to bring innovation through design thinking to marginalized youth. Before long Bilal was realizing that he was Saleh’s student as well.
We started asking the question. What would happen if instead of trying to help each other we lived together instead and had our exchanges come from a place of care. Then we started to wonder is it possible to expand this uncommon union to include more people, to create a structure that supported the financial and physical needs of those involved, while living from a place of compassion rather than obligation.
These questions grew into Beit Al Atlas. A semi-public and semi-private community home where we explore alternative care oriented ways of responding to the many challenges our modern times bring to us.
It’s been a challenge, and we are evolving and changing as we learn. We have made mistakes and I’d like to take this moment to publicly apologize to anyone who’s had a challenge in our house. Beit Al Atlas struggles financially, as well as infra-structurally and we’re continuously attempting to improve our communication processes. If after reading all this you’re still interested in participating as a house mate, a part time resident and house contributor, or hosting an event in our public space please message us on Facebook and we’ll get back to you soon.

 **Beit Al Atlas (بيت الأطلس)**
The name refers to the Atlantic Ocean (بحر الأطلس) . A vast space which encompasses great difference. Touches east, touches west and holds it all in a unified self sustaining ecosystem.
About the house:
Beit Al Atlas is a community house based in Beirut Lebanon. Our mission is to stretch ourselves to live across difference. We are a semi-public semi-private space. Our upstairs and rooftop area are open for workshops and events with an emphasis on activities which embody and enact some of our core mission. The first floor of our house is reserved for the 5 residents.
We’re also establishing a residency in our second floor public area for those who want to come to Beirut and live for shorter durations and contribute in a deeper more meaningful way. To meet with the reality of this city we’ve grown to love.
Please reach out on out facebook page if you’re curious to rent our public area, considering living with us, or simply want to come by for tea. We’re always open for tea.

To the Honorable Judge,

I am writing this letter as a character witness for Saleh [Last Name], whom I have known for [length of time] through our work together at Beit Al Atlas, a community house in Beirut that he co-founded two years ago.

Throughout our time working together, Saleh has consistently demonstrated exceptional character qualities that make him a valued member of our community. His journey from student to co-founder of Beit Al Atlas exemplifies his capacity for growth, leadership, and vision. What began as him participating in a UNICEF-funded youth innovation project evolved into him becoming a teacher and mentor to others, including myself.

Saleh's commitment to creating spaces of care and compassion is evident in the founding principles of Beit Al Atlas. Rather than approaching community support through traditional charitable models, he helped envision and build a home where people live together in mutual care and respect across differences. This innovative approach to addressing social challenges demonstrates his thoughtfulness and dedication to meaningful change.

In all my interactions with Saleh, he has proven himself to be trustworthy, reliable, and unfailingly generous with his time and resources. His hospitality extends beyond mere courtesy—it reflects a deep commitment to building bridges between people of different backgrounds and creating inclusive spaces where all feel welcome.

Despite facing financial and infrastructural challenges at Beit Al Atlas, Saleh has remained steadfast in his commitment to the community, continuously working to improve communication and address difficulties with honesty and integrity.

I believe Saleh's character and contributions to our community speak to his fundamental decency and positive impact on those around him. I hope this letter provides helpful context in your considerations.

Respectfully,
[Your Name]

---

Now, let me ask you 5 questions that will help me write a more detailed and compelling letter:

1. **Specific Examples**: Can you share a specific story or incident where Saleh demonstrated his kindness, generosity, or reliability? Perhaps a time when he went above and beyond for someone in need?

2. **Your Relationship**: How long have you known Saleh, and in what capacity? Are you a co-founder, resident, frequent visitor, or connected in another way? This will help establish your credibility as a character witness.

3. **Community Impact**: Beyond Beit Al Atlas, has Saleh been involved in other community projects or initiatives? What specific positive changes has he brought to the neighborhood or broader community?

4. **Legal Context**: Without going into details of the case, is there a particular aspect of his character that would be most relevant to emphasize? (For example, if it's related to financial matters, his honesty and transparency would be key; if it's about conflict, his peaceful nature and conflict resolution skills)

5. **Personal Qualities**: Can you describe how Saleh handles adversity or conflict? How does he treat people who might be considered vulnerable or marginalized in society?

These details will help me craft a more personalized and impactful letter that truly captures who Saleh is as a person.

---

To the Honorable Judge,

I am writing to offer my wholehearted character testimony for Saleh [Last Name], whom I have had the privilege of knowing since 2016. Our relationship began when Saleh was my student in a UNICEF-funded youth innovation program, but it quickly evolved into one of mutual learning and deep friendship. We co-founded Beit Al Atlas together, and I lived with him in this community home for three years until August 2019.

Throughout our eight years of friendship and collaboration, Saleh has consistently demonstrated extraordinary kindness and reliability. He embodies the Arabic concept of "karam" (generosity) in ways both large and small. He has picked me up from the airport countless times without being asked. When I see him cooking maafsil, I know it's because he remembers it's my favorite dish. When my son was born, Saleh honored our family by performing an udhiya—a gesture that reflected his deep respect for tradition and his care for those he considers family.

Saleh's compassion extends to all living beings. When he encountered a dog being abused, he didn't simply walk by—he adopted Lulu, who has now become a beloved member of the Beit Al Atlas family. This act exemplifies his inability to ignore suffering and his commitment to creating spaces of safety and care.

His leadership during crisis has been remarkable. When the Beirut blast devastated our city in 2020, Saleh immediately opened Beit Al Atlas to those who had suddenly lost their homes. He spent days cooking for displaced families while we scrambled to fundraise for emergency support. His response wasn't calculated or performative—it was the natural extension of who he is.

For years, Saleh has been a cultural bridge for Beirut, hosting journalists, artists, and students from around the world. He doesn't just provide them shelter; he integrates them into Lebanese life, taking them camping in our mountains and teaching them about our culture with patience and joy. The house has become a hub for creative projects like Celine's writing club and countless fundraisers, including one that helped our Syrian community member Abed obtain his passport—a life-changing document for a refugee.

What strikes me most about Saleh is his consistency. Whether dealing with a flood in the house, financial struggles, or the daily challenges of running a community space, he approaches each situation with the same steady reliability and care. He has built something rare in our fractured world: a space where people across religious, national, and economic differences live together in genuine community.

If I needed anything—truly anything—I know without doubt that Saleh would find a way to help. This isn't mere friendship; it's the kind of trust built over years of watching someone consistently choose kindness, even when it's difficult or costly.

I offer this testimony with complete confidence in Saleh's character. He represents the best of what community can be in Beirut, and I trust the court will see the person I have been honored to know.

With respect,

[Your Name]
[Your Title/Profession]
[Contact Information]
[Date]

---

To the Honorable Judge,

I'm writing about my friend Saleh [Last Name], whom I've known since 2016. We co-founded Beit Al Atlas together and lived in the same house for three years.

To the Honorable Judge,

I'm writing about my friend Saleh [Last Name], whom I've known since 2016. We co-founded Beit Al Atlas together and lived in the same house for three years until I moved out in 2019.

Saleh is one of the most genuinely kind people I know. He's the type of person who picks you up from the airport without being asked, who remembers your favorite food and cooks it for you. When my son was born, he did an udhiya for us. When he was back in the refugee camp where he grew up and saw a dog trapped on a roof without food, he rescued her - Lulu is still with the house family today.

Growing up, Saleh witnessed the Syrian conflict firsthand. With the recent war and escalating violence in Lebanon, I understand he got some things for self-defense - just like many people in Beirut did when we started hearing bombs again. But I lived with him for three years and saw him handle every kind of stress - floods, money problems, conflicts between residents. He always responded with patience. His instinct is to protect and provide, not to harm.

When the Beirut blast happened, Saleh opened the house to anyone who needed shelter. He cooked for days straight while we figured out how to help. He doesn't have much money, but our house is always open. Over the years, he's hosted hundreds of visitors - journalists, students, artists - helping them understand Beirut, taking them camping, making sure they feel at home.

The house has become a real community center. We host writing clubs, fundraisers, all sorts of gatherings. When our Syrian friend Abed needed help getting his passport, Saleh organized the fundraiser. That's who he is - someone who sees a problem and quietly works to fix it.

I trust Saleh completely. Even though I haven't lived there since 2019, I know if I ever needed help, he'd be there. He's been running Beit Al Atlas for years now, creating a space where people from different backgrounds live together peacefully. In a city like Beirut, especially during these difficult times, that takes real strength and patience.

Respectfully,
